mxCell.value: I named my budget!

<<Accounts>>

The first thing we'll do is name your budget!  

Click here and select "Rename Budget" and type it in!

I like to call mine "My Wealthy Plan"
move_to: budget_name

<<Accounts>>

Cool name! Now let's add your accounts.
Account Setup Process

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account" and give your account a name. For example, something like "Main Checking"

For the Type, select 'For Budget: Checking' then enter the current balance of your Checking account.

<<Accounts>>

Awesome! Now, Select + Add Account!
I got my balance!

<<Accounts>>

We'll start with your Checking Account. 

To make things easier you'll need to log into your bank and see the current balance. 

Come back to me when you've got that information!

NO
credit_cards = no

<<Accounts>>

Do you have credit cards that you use regularly? (Yes/No)

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account." Name your account, select a Type of 'For Budget: Credit Card' and then enter the current balance of that account.

<<Accounts>>

Ready? Select + Add Account!

<<Accounts>>

For this step, you'll need to log in to your credit card account (try to not use general terms such as bank/account...) and see the current balance. Come back to me when you've got that information!

YES
credit_cards = yes
move_to: add_account
Budget Summary Overview
I clicked Budget!

Your budget is your wealth building plan! This is a key tool for you to achieve your financial goals.

When you're ready, Click the "Budget" tab.

<<Budget>>

Let me show you how to navigate your budget!

Here, you can select which month you want to view your budget.
I clicked 2 calendars!

<<Budget>>

What's cool is that you can actually view multiple months to compare. 

Click the calendar icons to choose how many months you want to view. 

I like to keep it simple and compare my current month to either the last one to see what has changed or with the next month to help me plan ahead.

Give it a try!
move_to: calendar_icons

<<Budget>>

Great! So this purple band will highlight the months that you are viewing and you'll see your budget summary.
move_to: months_band

<<Budget>>

This is how much money you have to budget. 

Now, I'll show you how to set up your budget!
move_to: budget_header
I'm ready!
Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

Here is where you'll see everything you're budgeting for.

<<Budget>>

These are your categories, which can be customized.

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is the amount of money you're budgeting for each category.

<<Budget>>

Spent, shows you how much you actually spent in each category

<<Budget>>

Last, is your leftover balance. This shows you how much of your budget you have left. If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category. If the amount is black, you still have some money leftover!
I'll pay attention to my budget!

<<Budget>>

The goal is to stay as close to your budget as possible to make progress!

The more you overspend, the likelihood you'll see your checking account balance go down. This is where the stress happens with overdrafts, potential fees, and dips into your savings!

We don't want that!
Let's see the example

<<Budget>>

Good! That's what I want to see!

If you hover over a row you will see an arrow appear. You can add, hide, or delete a category. 

Let's walk through an example.
That's a cool feature

<<Budget>>

Hover over one of your main category groups.

Now, add a category. 

Type in "fun activities"

<<Budget>>
Yeah, it's pretty handy.

Are you ready to build out your budget?
Add Transaction

<<Accounts>>
Click "+ Add New" and select today's date.
move_to: add_new_button

<<Accounts>>

Let's categorize this as "Bills"

<<Accounts>>

Now, complete this transaction by clicking the check mark so that it turns green.

<<Accounts>>

Pretty straightforward, right? Notice that the account balance decreased by $100? 

The goal is to pay attention to how much money you have left every time you spend!
move_to: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

Great! Now let me show you how to delete a transaction.

Select the transaction (left box next to the date).

<<Accounts>>

You are doing great!

Next, we'll set up your budget! 

Feel free to take a break if you need to.

<<Accounts>>

Select the purple text with '1 transaction'.

Select 'Delete' to remove that transaction.
Let's do this!

<<Accounts>>

I'm going to break things down one step at a time and show you how to use the program. ðŸ˜Š

If at any point you want to review anything we've talked about, just select the back button!

<<Accounts>>

Remember, this is not a live chat. I'm going to show you the ropes, but if you have any questions, you can always find some time on my calendar here!
move_to: zoom_link
Sounds Good!
Great! Let's get started!

<<Accounts>>

We'll keep it simple. I'll show you how to:
1. Set Up Your Accounts
2. Create Your Budget
3. Track Your Expenses 

Once you know the basics, you'll have the option to choose which topics you want me to go over!

Database - can keep responses and reference later on; not all questions need the database capture. The second line of the response selected is the database code. If not planning to reference answer later or drive flow based on response in another section, don't need second line.

<<Accounts>> / <<Budget>>

This aligns the avatar with which screen the user should be on. If a user goes to the Budget at a step where the avatar flow has <<Accounts>>, or if the user goes to an Account while the avatar is on Budget, the user will see the following message:

 Please navigate to the Accounts {Budget} to continue our conversation (please select an account).

Please Note: There needs to be a blank line between the reference to Accounts/Budget and the text shown in the avatar window.
I'm ready to set up my budget!
Trusting Your Numbers

One of the complexities for users with a zero-based budgeting software is the due diligence to ensure the account balances in MyBudgetCoach match the account balances in the financial institution. 

A difficult part of having the accounts match is ensuring the starting balance set by the user at the time the accounts are added are accurate. For checking accounts, some banks include pending transactions in the Current Balance. If the starting balance includes pending transactions, then when the transactions are added, they will be double counted. For credit cards, the Current Balance doesn't include pending transactions, so this is not an issue. 

Coach can consider consulting Coach Trainers to add a flow for verifying starting balance.
...one last thing before I leave you to your budgeting...
Of course
Can you answer 3 short questions for me? I want to make sure I continue to improve how helpful I am!
I submitted the form
Great! Here's the link: https://airtable.com/appYAaDkGzB3ecOzl/shrUnpE9sHBWWDMyB
Thanks so much! Happy budgeting!
User Survey after Tutorial
Credit Card Overview
Budget Skills
Close out the conversation
Remind about booking a call

Coach option to offer email for users to contact you directly prior to a call. Could help with triaging if a call is needed, versus hopping on a call and then realizing there isn't enough information.

People who have Credit Card balances in excess of their available dollars in their checking account will have a negative amount To Budgeted. This is an important step for the user, but can be handled in a various number of ways. Consider the main steps the user needs to complete, and then determine as the coach if you want to add more detail for any of those steps:

1) Adding the Credit Card Category Group
2) Add a Category for each Credit Card
3) Changing the category on the account side of the Credit Card starting balance to the newly created Category
4) Rollover overspending if not going to pay off balance

This will give the user back their dollars in their checking account in the To Budgeted.

Hi [[user_first_name]]! Welcome to MyBudgetCoach! MyBudgetCoach is a unique budgeting software that comes along with a virtual avatar. You selected, me, Jenny, as your personal coach! Yay!

I'm excited for you to budget your way to wealthy life!

delete_category_group: Usual Expenses
delete_category_group: Investments and Savings
create_category_group: Housing
create_category: Housing: Mortgage/Rent
create_category_group: Bills + Utilities
create_category: Bills + Utilities: Insurance
create_category: Bills + Utilities: Phone
create_category: Bills + Utilities: Gas + Electric
create_category: Bills + Utilities: Water
create_category: Bills + Utilities: Internet + Cable
create_category: Bills + Utilities: Trash
create_category: Bills + Utilities: Subscriptions
create_category_group: Auto + Transport
create_category: Auto + Transport: Auto Payment
create_category: Auto + Transport: Gas
create_category: Auto + Transport: Auto Maintenance
create_category: Auto + Transport: Ride Shares
create_category: Auto + Transport: Parking
create_category: Auto + Transport: Public Transport
create_category_group: Food + Dining
create_category: Food + Dining: Groceries
create_category: Food + Dining: Dining Out
create_category: Food + Dining: Food Delivery
create_category_group: Personal Expenses
create_category: Personal Expenses: Personal Care
create_category: Personal Expenses: Shopping
create_category_group: Health + Wellness
create_category: Health + Wellness: Fitness Memberships
create_category: Health + Wellness: Medical Expenses
create_category_group: Travel + Activities
create_category: Travel + Activities: Events + Activities
create_category: Travel + Activities: Travel
create_category_group: Gifts + Donations
create_category: Gifts + Donations: Gifts
create_category: Gifts + Donations: Donations
Budget Setup

You as the Coach can do as much or as little as you would like for the user. For example, if you just want to add a handful of categories, or walk them through how to edit and add themselves, that is fine. Alternatively, you could have the system build an entire budget with defined groups, and categories, so when they select the button before the template is built, it automatically updates.

Some coaches have built the table in phases, others offer the option of just groups, and the user adds categories, or the user adds everything. Full discretion to the coach!

<<Budget>>

Yay! You got your budget set up and ready to go! Feel free to add, remove, or edit the categories to fit YOUR life!
Use Jenny's Template

<<Budget>>

If you want, you can use my budget category template and I'll build it out for you right now.

You won't be able to undo this step, but you'll be able to customize it afterwards.

<<Budget>>

How to move money into your categories:

Select your To Budget amount in purple; 

Enter how much you want to budget and select the category you're budgeting.  

Click Transfer
Okay, I will pay attantion!

<<Budget>>

Pay attention to the balance that you have left for each category. Remember, if it's red, that means you've overspent in that budget!
Don't Edit - Keep link and keep text
This is the end of the introduction conversation. A user can reset the conversation under the Manage Coach section.

<<Budget>>

Steps for Adding the Credit Card Category Group

<<Budget>>

Steps for Adding a Credit Card Category for each card under the Group.

Last flow should include transition to the account side.

<<Accounts>>

Steps for changing the Starting Balance transaction to have a Category of the applicable newly created Credit Card Category.

Transition back to budget

<<Budget>>

Rollover overspending to allow credit card balance to continue into future months so that the user doesn't have to fund the full balance in the current month.

<<Accounts>>

Ok, first question! Are you budgeting with a partner or just for yourself?

Yes, with a partner!
partner = yes

Nope, just me.
partner = no

<<Accounts>>

Cool! Budgeting was a HUGE tool for me throughout my personal finance journey. It helped me get rid of $100k worth of debt and build a 6-figure net worth. I did it all by myself, so you can too!

Next
partner_name = [user_input]

<<Accounts>>

Ok great! What's your partner's name?

<<Accounts>>
I look forward to working with you and [[partner_name]] throughout the tutorial! 

Budgeting helped me get rid of $100k worth of debt and build a 6 figure net worth. I'm excited for what you'll both achieve on your journey!!
We're Ready!
I'm Ready!

<<Accounts>>

WooHoo! Now, I'll show you how to add a transaction.

 We'll use a cell phone bill as an example.

Don't worry, I'll show you how to delete it afterwards.

What kind of device?

Consider asking a user what type of device they are using. If using a computer, the current language for how to access options works. If using a tablet, somethings are different (tap versus hover; double click versus single click...). Can utilize the IF syntax to adjust the response in a box where overviewing how to use software dependent on the device the user has.

Buttons default to 'Next' if no text is added on line. Button text can be short, or long (even two sentences) and include emojis. If have multiple lines due to a question, can program button text for each line.
Consider having a question to create a break for the user. Could also reference the earlier list of steps to complete, and show progress by crossing out those pieces that are done.
Additional Conversations
Simple FIN

MyBudgetCoach has a direct import option. A coach can either walk through in detail how to complete this, or they can create a separate conversation for if a user to click through at a later point if interested.

Accounts can be linked at any time, so if added manually, can then link for direct import later on.

Linking direct import immediately can be helpful as SimpleFIN's connection will automatically set the starting balance. But the process takes some time and for a new user, they may want to make progress on the software itself and not spend 10-15 minutes just setting up direct import. 

Could always recommend they delete prior accounts, and add new ones once SimpleFIN is linked. This first budget is just a test to get started. Set up real budget with your actual accounts and setting up.
Show me how to Import
I'll be sure to import frequently

<<Accounts>>

This 'Import' button allows you to upload your transactions from your bank.

Most banks will allow you to download a QIF, OFX, or QFX file of your transactions. You will want to use ones of these files to import.

The other option is to import a CSV file.

Remember to do this frequently throughout the month!
move_to: import_button

<<Accounts>>

Great! I'm rooting for you!

If you want to search for specific transactions, you can use the filter button.
move_to: filter_button

<<Accounts>>

Or you can use the search bar. You can search by amount, the date, or even description.
move_to: search_bar

<<Accounts>>

This is the 'Split/Toggle' button. If you happen to have split transactions, this button will expand or collapse those transactions from view.
move_to: split_toggle_button

<<Accounts>>

These three dots show additional options.

<<Accounts>>

So far we've

1. Got your Checking Account Set Up
2. Learned how to add, delete, and search transactions
move_to: more_button
Coach can decide how much explanation they want to provide for each of these. Reconciliation for example can be a complex discussion.

Let's type "AT&T"

You can always select "Cancel" to get out of adding transactions.

<<Budget>>

Okay let me show you a few more things. 

Below the categories is the 'Income' Section.

<<Budget>>

The Income row will show you the total amount of deposits to your bank account in a month.
move_to: received_column
I'm done!

<<Budget>>

Great! Now that you know how to add categories, you can also add any notes by hovering over the small paper icon in each row. 

You can note things like reminders of events you are budgeting for or specific bill due dates. This is your space!

All boxes don't need to have <<Accounts>> or <<Budget>>. If you remove this, that means the user can be in either screen and the avatar will continue. This can help with transitions from one section to another.
I'm ready to budget!

<<Budget>>

Now that the template is all ready and your categories are good to go, let's show you how to actually adjust your budget.

<<Budget>>

Alright! You now know the basics to get you started on creating and managing your budget!
 
We can go over other topics later when you're ready, such as credit cards, loans, and budgeting tips!
This section could be very extensive, or you could keep it high level and create a separate conversation the next time the user gets paid.
Button Text

<<Accounts>>

Part 1 of the credit cards overview is completed. Now for part 2, editing the Budget Table for the credit card.

<<Accounts>>

Instruct user to flip over to Budget to add Categories for each of their cards.

Consider asking the user the question if they are planning to pay off the current balance (not the statement balance) in-full.
Credit Card wrap-up; Move to wrap-up and good-bye of introduction avatar.

<<Accounts>>

This section is split into two parts:

1) Adding account(s), test transaction, and payments.
2) Budget updates

First off, let's check if you have any credit card accounts.

<<Accounts>>

Click "+ Add New" and select today's date.

<<Accounts>>

For the category, select the appropriate category from your budget table. You can start typing the category name and have the list of available categories filter down.

Finish this transaction by selecting the check mark to turn it green.

<<Accounts>>

Notice the account balance has increased by $75.
move_to: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

Type "Grocery Store" as your Payee.

move_to: select_category

Now, enter $75 in the Payment box.
move_to: payment_input

Now click "Add". 

Please note, you can select "Cancel" to get out of adding transactions.
move_to: cleared_status_icon
move_to: save_transaction
Button Text

<<Accounts>>

Explain the inverse relationship with credit cards vs bank accounts. Payments increase the balance, Deposits decrease the balance. This is because credit cards are negative balances so the inverse occurs.

<<Accounts>>

Let's delete this pretend transaction. Go ahead and hover on the left side of the date to un-hide a box. Select the box to select the transaction.
Button Text

<<Accounts>>

Introduce how to add a transfer transaction. For example, making a payment to a credit card.

<<Accounts>>

Explain the sections of a transfer: Select 'Transfer To / From' in the Payee; no Category; transaction automatically added in other account.

<<Accounts>>

To the right hand side of the search box, select the purple text with '1 transaction' to see a series of options.

Select 'Delete' to remove that transaction.
Could ask the user if they have more than one card. Could limit to just one or two they use most frequently.
Could ask the user if they plan to pay off card in-full. If they do, don't need to complete the steps. If they don't, steps are important.
Could ask the user if they see a negative Red Overbudgeted number, or if it is less than they expected.
move_to: selected_transactions_button
I know how to add transactions now!
I'll stick with manual transactions

<<Accounts>>

Awesome! You'll learn a lot about where your money goes by tracking this way.

Remember to enter your transactions frequently! I recommend daily, if not weekly!
I'll enter my transactions frequently!

<<Budget>>

Now, if you hover over the "fun activities" row, you can delete it!
Done, what's next?
I don't need an example

<<Budget>>

Awesome! Go ahead and add your budget categories and come back when you're done!
I'll create my own
I'm done!

Just as a reminder, you can always book a call if you need any support!

If you have a quick question or you're not sure whether you should book a call, feel free to email me at: jenny@worththehappiness.com

<<Accounts>>

This is how you can manually track your transactions and if you've NEVER tracked your expenses this way before, I highly recommend trying it for 30 consistent days. It will help you be more aware of where your money is going and help you build a habit of looking at your expenses!

<<Accounts>>

The other option is to import your transactions from your bank statement. If you choose to do this, I recommend importing at LEAST every week. If you wait until the end of the month, you won't be able to actually adjust your spending to your budget.

<<Accounts>>

Okay! Let's add one more credit card account to capture your total expenses.

<<Accounts>>

Select "+Add Account", click "Create Local Account."

Name your account, select a Type of "For Budget: Credit Card", and then enter the current balance of that account.

<<Budget>>

You want to plan on Budgeting dollars to make a payment of at least your minimum payment for each account.

<<Accounts>>

Thanks for your answer! Let's now add the credit card account that is used the most often of your remaining accounts.

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account." Name your account, select a Type of 'For Budget: Credit Card' and then enter the current balance of that account.

<<Accounts>>

That wraps up adding accounts. Let's move now to adding transactions on a credit card account.

<<Accounts>>

How many transactions per week occur on your remaining credit card account?

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account." Name your account, select a Type of 'For Budget: Credit Card' and then enter the current balance of that account.
highlight: selected_transactions_button

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Create Local Account." Name your account, select a Type of 'For Budget: Credit Card' and then enter the current balance of that account.

<<Accounts>>

As you continue to use MyBudgetCoach, please keep in mind each account requires reconciliation, a few times a week, and categorizing of transactions.

Great work learning the differences with credit card transactions. The next portion of this section is to review the impact to the Budget Summary and Table as a result of adding credit card account(s).
Got it
5 or Less transactions

<<Budget>>

Because you will be carrying some debt over to next month, there a few additional steps we will walk through to make sure MyBudgetCoach works properly for you.

<<Accounts>>

If at a later point you would like to add additional credit card accounts, you can select this conversation again to start from the beginning.

<<Accounts>>

Based on the number of transactions that occur per week, I would recommend leaving out the additional account for now, and then if you would like to add it on a future date, feel free!
Yes; Let's review those steps again

<<Accounts>>

Based on the number of transactions that occur per week, let's add one more account so your expenses can be accurately captured each month.
No; All set

Congratulations on setting up a credit card in the Budget!

Is there another Credit Card account where you would like to walk through the Budget set-up process again?
Let's now move to Step 2. For this, we will shift from the Budget to the Accounts section and select a credit card account.
More than 5 transactions
Ok! My credit card account category has been added. Step 1 complete!

<<Accounts>>

To summarize, you have added three credit card accounts.

<<Budget>>

Sure; Before we review those steps again, please create a new category within your Credit Card Group and name that category with the Credit Card Account name.
highlight: balance column

<<Accounts>>

How many additional credit
cards do you actively use each week?
I've got my card balance!

<<Budget>>

Now that you have added credit card account(s), your 'To Budget' number has been reduced by the total of the balance for the account(s) you just added. Let's walk through how to make the 'To Budget' number equal to what it was prior to adding the credit card account(s).
Two or more

<<Accounts>>

Let's start with the credit that you use the most. 

Please login to your bank so you can gather your current credit card balance. Come back to me when you've got that information!
highlight: add_account

<<Accounts>>

Please login to your bank so you can gather your current credit card balance.
move_to: budget_header
highlight: add_account

So, you want to add a credit card?

I'll walk you through the steps on how to add a credit card account and show you how MyBudgetCoach can help you budget with credit cards.

<<Accounts>>

Please login to your bank so you can gather your current credit card balance.
highlight: zoom_link

<<Accounts>>

Before we link a third credit card account, let me ask a follow-up question.
highlight: add_account

<<Budget>>

Because you can pay the balance in-full, and have a credit card category with a 'Balance' = 0, moving forward with your MyBudgetCoach use, you will be funding your categories outside of the credit card category. If you aren't accumulating any debt, have covered any overspent categories, than your credit card payment will be equal to your current balance.
highlight: add_account

For the credit card account(s) you added, are there any that you plan to pay off the current balance at the end of this month?

Please note, by 'current balance' I am referring to the balance you entered when you added the account. This is not the statement balance, which is a balance as of an earlier date.
You can complete the 'Calculate Credit Card Payment' conversation at any time to assist in determining what your credit card payment should be.

<<Accounts>>

Please login to your bank so you can gather your current credit card balance.

<<Budget>>

Give yourself some grace and remember, reducing your debt is a journey and takes dedication. You already have started working toward your goal by using this budgeting software and working through this conversation to learn more!

<<Budget>>

If you have more than one credit card account, you will need to complete the following steps for each account.

<<Budget>>

Step 1 is to create a Category Group called 'Credit Cards.' Under that Category Group, you would add a Category for each of the credit card account(s) you added.

Let me add this for you as a starting point...

<<Budget>>

OK! Step 1 is completed. Please scroll down to the bottom of your budget table to find the Credit Card category group and rename the newly created category to your specific credit card account name.

create_category_group: Credit Cards
create_category: Credit Cards: Credit Card Account

<<Accounts>>

The first transaction should be the transaction that was added when you first added the account. You should see an amount in the 'Payment' column that equals the balance on the day you added the account.

<<Accounts>>

Now that we have created the category on the Budget for the Credit Card Account, we are going to change the Category from 'Starting Balance' to the newly created category for your Credit Card Account.
Great work! Now, lets go back to the Budget and see what happened with the 'Spent' and 'Balance' columns in the Credit Card Account category.

<<Budget>>

Scroll down to the credit card category of the account you just updated. Now the 'Spent' column is a negative number that equals your balance you entered previously.

<<Budget>>

Since the 'Budgeted' column for the category is 0, the 'Balance' is a negative red number and is equal to 'Spent.'
highlight: spent_column

<<Budget>>

The last step, Step 3, is to complete the actions for how you want MyBudgetCoach to handle the debt associated with the credit card. You have some options, so let me first ask you a question so I can tailor my guidance.

<<Budget>>

Good for you! KUDOS on managing your debt. Very few people with a credit card balance have the cash flow to pay in-full at any time.

<<Budget>>

To fund your balance you enter the amount of your credit card balance in the Budgeted column of your newly created credit card category. This will update the 'Balance' to be 0 since you budgeted dollars to equal the current balance of the credit card.

<<Budget>>

When you Budgeted the dollars, the purple number at the top of the Budget Summary in the 'To Budget' went down.

<<Budget>>

You can now budget with confidence the rest of your available dollars to your remaining categories, until your 'To Budget' number is 0. If you would like to learn more about this process, select the 'Make To Budget Equal to 0' conversation to work through that conversation when you have completed this conversation.

<<Budget>>

We need to allow the remaining balance you don't pay off this current month, to continue to future months, since your credit card company will continue to have that balance carry over until you pay it off.

<<Budget>>

MyBudgetCoach has a unique feature that is called 'Rollover overspending.' This option allows a user to have the debt continue into future months, instead of paying off this month, so you can pay it off overtime.

<<Budget>>

Selecting the 'Rollover overspending' option increases your 'To Budget' number in the current month, since the debt has now been rolled over to future months.

<<Budget>>

Select the negative amount in red text in the Balance column of your Credit Card Account Category. Within the option menu that comes up, select the 'Rollover overspending' option.

To see the system roll the debt over to a future month, select the option in the top left to show two months at a time by selecting the 2nd calendar icon.

<<Budget>>

The arrow to the right of the amount in the Balance column is how MyBudgetCoach alerts you to the fact you have rolled over the overspending for future months. This option will stay turned on for all future months, unless you select to 'Remove overspending rollover.'

<<Budget>>

When you budget to the category it reduces the debt immediately. You'll still have to submit a payment through your credit card account, but you can see your progress in the category right away.

<<Budget>>

To handle interest applied to your credit card account(s), if applicable, you would categorize that transaction to the Category of your Credit Card Account, just like how you updated the Starting Balance category.

<<Budget>>

Credit Cards can be complex, especially if you have more than one credit card account. I am available for a one-on-one call at your convenience to help answer any questions you may have in your future use of MyBudgetCoach.

<<Accounts>>

The important difference between a bank account and a credit card account is that for a credit card account, Payments INCREASE the balance, and Deposits DECREASE the balance. This is because a credit card balance is negative.

<<Accounts>>

Please select your main credit card account. You will now add two hypothetical transactions.

<<Accounts>>

Please select '+ Add New,' select today's date and enter a Payee of 'Cell Phone Company.'

<<Accounts>>

Select an applicable category and enter a Payment amount of 100, Clear the transaction, and select Add.

<<Accounts>>

Let's now add a transaction for a credit card payment. Credit Card payments are Transfers and entered as a Deposit.

<<Accounts>>

The credit card balance, a red negative number, has now increased by 100.

<<Accounts>>

Please select '+ Add New,' select today's date, and for the Payee, select 'Make Transfer.' Within the 'Transfer To/From' list of accounts, select your checking account.

<<Accounts>>

The Category field is now populated with Transfer. Enter 100 in the 'Deposit' field, since this is a payment to reduce the credit card balance, and select Add.

<<Accounts>>

Let's now jump over to the checking account.

<<Accounts>>

Since you selected 'Make Transfer' as the Payee in your credit card account, this automatically added a transaction to your checking account as well.

<<Accounts>>

Please take note that the credit card payment is an outflow in the Payment column for the checking account, but an inflow in the Deposit column for the credit card. This is because your payment reduces a negative balance (Deposit) in the credit card account and reduces the positive balance (Payment) in the checking account.

<<Accounts>>

KUDOS on creating transactions for both accounts!

<<Accounts>>

Before we move to the next step, let's delete those two credit card transactions you added.

<<Accounts>>

Please navigate back to your main credit card account and select each of the two transactions using the box to the left of the date. Then select the link named '2 transactions' to the right of the search bar and choose Delete.
highlight: add_new_button

This is what we will complete together. 

1. Adding Credit Card Account(s)
2. Adding Credit Card transactions
3. Updating Budget Table based on pay off plan
4. Determining your current debt management strategy

Please select 'All Accounts' to continue the conversation.
Thanks for your help!
Great work setting up your Credit Card accounts in MyBudgetCoach! This ends this conversation. Bye for now...
